comments.content: C is correct according with Cisco pdf link

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
IEEE 802.3bz (mGig or N-BASET) can be used on CAT5e cabling up to 100 meters long. This standard allows for speeds of 2.5 Gbps and 5 Gbps on existing twisted-pair copper cabling
According to Ethernet standards, the maximum length of a Cat5e cable run is 100 meters (or 328 feet). It is possible to go further by using a POE repeater.

Selected Answer: B
An engineer has deployed Cisco Aironet 3800 Series APs with switches that support 802.11bz on existing CAT-5e cabling. Which value is the maximum distance supported to achieve up to 5 Gb speed?
When deploying Cisco Aironet 3800 Series APs with switches that support 802.11bz on existing CAT-5e cabling, the maximum distance supported to achieve up to 5 Gb speed is 30-50 meters

comments.content:
Keep lengths of CAT-5e between 30-50m or below when using dense cable bundles; for example, cables in a dense area like a pipe or places where five or more cables are tied in a bundle.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/technotes/8-3/b_cisco_aironet_series_2800_3800_access_point_deployment_guide/b_cisco_aironet_series_2800_3800_access_point_deployment_guide_chapter_0101.pdf

questions.question_text: An engineer has deployed Cisco Aironet 3800 Series APs with switches that support 802.11bz on existing CAT-5e cabling. Which value is the maximum distance supported to achieve up to 5 Gb speed?

choices.C: Enable coverage hole detection and BSS transition and disable dissociation imminent.
choices.B: Enable the BSS transition option with an optimized roaming timer for the corporate SSID.
choices.A: Enable BSS transition for the SSID and disable dissociation imminent to avoid client disconnects.
choices.D: Disable coverage hole detection and enable 802.11k for the corporate SSID.

questions.question_text: A network engineer is working for an enterprise where most of the laptops support 802.11v. To optimize the client roaming experience, configuration changes must be made on the corporate SSID to force clients to use the best APs based on the 802.11 v BSS transition message. Which configuration meets this requirement?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is right answer ,optimized roaming

Selected Answer: B
When unsolicited optimized roaming request is triggered, the AP sends a BSS Transition Management Request to the client and wait for a certain period (time configured under Optimized Roaming Disassociation Timer), if the client does not roam to a better AP within that period of time, then the AP completes the disassociation of the client.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

Selected Answer: C
Set the scale first of all

Selected Answer: B
having scale is important

questions.question_text: An engineer must perform a predictive wireless survey to indicate the number of access points required. The engineer has created a new project and imported the floor plan. Which step must be taken next for accurate AP placement?

In a multifloor office building that contains an auditorium in the basement, all the access points are joined to the same WLC. The plan is to implement a high-density, high-speed design in the auditorium and a low-density VoWiFi design in the offices. How must the access point groups be configured for the auditorium and the offices?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct , we can not use same profile for all and for different application. Also we have one WLC then D is wrong

choices.B: Join the access points in each area to area-specific access point groups that have separate RF profiles.
choices.D: Join the access points in each area to different controllers that have separate RF profiles.
choices.A: To all the access points, apply one RF profile that supports Vo WLAN.
choices.C: To all the access points, apply one RF profile that supports high speed.

choices.B: Set the XOR radio role to Monitor mode and the slot 1 radio to Client Serving on all the APs.
choices.A: Set the XOR radio role to Client Serving and the slot 1 radio to Sniffer mode on all the APs.
choices.D: Set the XOR radio role to Sniffer mode and the slot 1 radio to Client Serving on all the APs.
choices.C: Set the XOR radio role to Client Serving and the slot 1 radio to Monitor mode on all the APs.

questions.question_text:
A customer has a Cisco wireless network that has these configurations and components:

• two Cisco Catalyst 9800 Series WLCs in a high availability cluster
• 50 Cisco 2800I APs
• all SSIDs and services are 5 GHz only

A security mandate requires that rogue APs be scanned and identified in 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz bands and must not impact existing client connectivity. How must the wireless network be reconfigured to meet the requirement without purchasing additional APs?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The Cisco 2800 Series APs have a dual-radio architecture, which includes:
Slot 1 (5 GHz radio) → Typically used for client connectivity.
XOR Radio (Software-Defined Radio, 2.4 GHz or 5 GHz) → Can be configured in different roles. And if we want to find rogue AP we need to use XOR radios on Monitor mode.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct.

Sniffer mode should not be considered in this scenario because it is primarily used for capturing and analyzing network traffic, which can disrupt normal network operations.

The XOR radio offer the ability to serve 2.4–GHz or 5–GHz bands or passively monitor both the bands on the same AP. These APs can be configured to serve clients in 2.4–GHz and 5–GHz bands, or serially scan both 2.4–GHz and 5–GHz bands on the flexible radio while the main 5–GHz radio serves clients.

D. Set the XOR radio role to Sniffer mode and the slot 1 radio to Client Serving on all the APs.

This setup allows the APs to monitor both the 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz bands for rogue APs while continuing to serve client devices on the 5 GHz band, ensuring that existing client connectivity is not impacted.
